#AlanKelly	unknown-#AlanKelly-party	unknown-#AlanKelly-dob	unknown-#AlanKelly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	138	The Taoiseach could have said that.

#HollyCairns	unknown-#HollyCairns-party	unknown-#HollyCairns-dob	unknown-#HollyCairns-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	139	In recent weeks a school in west Cork has told its early intervention classes to close. After a local campaign this decision was rightly reversed
column2: which is welcome news. However
column3: it is still of huge concern that the National Council for Special Education
column4: NCSE
column5: plans to phase out early intervention classes nationwide in favour of the access and inclusion model. Needless to say
column6: that would be a disaster. Since then I have been doing my best to try to get answers. At a committee meeting last week the NCSE had a worrying and evasive response. Where we would expect it to say that is absolutely not the case
column7: it said it is waiting on the findings of an access and inclusion model
column8: AIM
column9: report and did not want to comment. Since then it and the Department have just ignored my questions so today thanks to the Ceann Comhairle I raised it with the Minister for Education at the Topical Issue debate and she also did not answer the question. I do not expect him to know the answer in this exact moment but I have tried every other avenue to try to get an answer to this question
column10: so will the Taoiseach please look into it?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	140	In my days as Minister for Education
column2: I was responsible for bringing in early intervention classes
column3: especially language classes
column4: in national schools
column5: which proved to be highly effective in terms of outcomes for children with language difficulties
column6: in particular
column7: or other difficulties. I am a passionate believer in early intervention. I will discuss this with the Minister for Education. The National Council for Special Education has statutory remit and freedom to commission reviews and to put forward policies. We have to acknowledge that. Of course
column8: that does not take away our right to interrogate that policy. I believe in early intervention on the ground. We should not take away resources that are there already.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	141	In the programme for Government
column2: the Taoiseach committed to a shared future for all
column3: in the aftermath of Covid. He and the Tánaiste repeatedly said that workers who have played a key role in keeping our society going during Covid should get a reward. Will the Taoiseach comment on the shocking efforts by Aer Lingus
column4: the national flag carrier
column5: to try to impose a pay freeze on 1
column6: 000 ground staff until 2024 and a 10% reduction in its rostered allowances
column7: against which the workers have now voted twice? In the most recent result in the past few days
column8: 85% of the workers voted against this shocking attempt to cut their pay. These workers are faced with inflation which is now
column9: according to the Department of Finance
column10: looking as though it will go up to 7% because of events in Ukraine and Aer Lingus expects them to take effective pay cuts. Will the Taoiseach join with me in commending those workers in rejecting this disgraceful pay cut from a company that got huge amounts of public money-----

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	142	Deputy
column2: please.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	143	-----from this Government during the Covid pandemic?

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	144	The Deputy was correct in saying that the company received very substantial funding from Government through EWSS and other aviation supports
column2: both for airlines and airports
column3: during Covid-19. The airlines took a huge hit
column4: as we know
column5: throughout the pandemic. That has to be acknowledged as well. However
column6: the successful way to retain good quality employees
column7: staff and so on is to reward them and acknowledge their contribution during Covid-19. It was not their particular fault-----

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	145	The same company gave a 10% pay increase to British Airways workers. I forgot to say that.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	146	-----and there are mechanisms. We do not engage here in operational decisions of companies but
column2: clearly
column3: from basic principles and values
column4: workers' efforts should be acknowledged.

column1: #MichaelLowry	unknown-#MichaelLowry-party	unknown-#MichaelLowry-dob	unknown-#MichaelLowry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	147	A number of recent economic reports into the Irish horse sector have shown that the vast majority of people involved in this industry
column2: especially in horse breeding
column3: have small holdings with five breeding mares or less. The equine sector comes under the remit of the Department of Agriculture
column4: Food and the Marine
column5: but has not benefited from any capital investment grants or direct support from CAP. There are currently 27
column6: 000 farmers registered on the Department's database with equine premises. These farmers in Tipperary and throughout rural Ireland would greatly benefit from the inclusion of their sector in target agriculture modernisation schemes
column7: TAMS
column8: to be funded under the new CAP regime from January 2023. Essential infrastructure
column9: such as stabling
column10: arenas
column11: horse fencing
column12: outwintering paddocks and horse handling facilities should be incorporated and eligible for funding under the scheme. Will the Taoiseach request that the Minister for Agriculture
column13: Food and the Marine examine inclusion of this integral part of Irish agriculture in such a scheme and engage directly with representatives of the thoroughbred and sports sector?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	148	I thank the Deputy for raising the issue of equine farming. A variety of items are available in the suite of seven measures under TAMS. I understand that grant aid is available for horse stocks under the animal welfare and nutrient storage scheme and the young farmer capital investment scheme. That said
column2: I will talk to the Minister of State
column3: Deputy Heydon
column4: and the Minister
column5: Deputy McConalogue
column6: about the issues the Deputy has raised this morning to see whether more can be done.

column1: #MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	149	I raise the issue of a Tipperary farmer with the Taoiseach. Mr. Thomas Kennedy has written to the Taoiseach
column2: the Minister for Justice
column3: An Garda Síochána
column4: the land services regulatory authority and the Property Services Regulatory Authority to try to obtain justice. Mr. Kennedy bought and paid for land but believes a wrong has been committed and he has been wrongly imprisoned and put off his lands
column5: which he has farmed for 30 years. I have also reported these issues to all these agencies on Mr. Kennedy's behalf. He has been fighting for 20 years. He has written to the Taoiseach. Will the Taoiseach set up an independent inquiry into this? There are rogue elements within An Garda Síochána
column6: the Department
column7: solicitors and all involved in this. It is a murky business and it is not fair that a citizen of our country should be treated like this. The Taoiseach knows about it because he has written to him and handed letters to him. The Minister for Justice knows as well.

#CathalCrowe	unknown-#CathalCrowe-party	unknown-#CathalCrowe-dob	unknown-#CathalCrowe-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	157	There has been huge investment by the Government in primary education. I have heard many positive announcements by the Minister
column2: Deputy Foley
column3: in my constituency. There is one outlier
column4: though. Tubber national school dates back to the 1870s and is absolutely hemmed in and crowded. It is on a triangular site with two very busy roads straddling it. It has no space to expand. On certain days of the week
column5: the teachers ask the pupils to leave their schoolbags at home because they cannot fit in the classroom. I was a teacher for 16 years. I am alarmed by the conditions in the school. The Department of Education urgently needs to come out to inspect it. This needs to be green lighted for a new build on a new site that the school and diocese have acquired.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	158	I welcome the fact the Deputy has raised this issue. Obviously
column2: movement and progress is needed on it. He said the diocese had acquired a new site. The most significant thing in terms of a new school is that the site has been secured. I will speak to the Minister for Education but the fact that the site has been secured facilitates the progression of the project. If one does not get a site
column3: sometimes it can go on for far too long.

column1: #BrendanGriffinFG	unknown-#BrendanGriffinFG-party	unknown-#BrendanGriffinFG-dob	unknown-#BrendanGriffinFG-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	159	I ask the Taoiseach about the appalling situation in Ukraine. Will the Government and our EU partners give consideration to how best we can assist with Russian soldiers who are conscientious objectors to what is happening? Many are fighting a war they do not want to fight and are involved in situations where they are killing men
column2: women and children that they do not want to kill. Could this concept be explored by our Government and our EU partners to see whether there is something we can do to help?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	160	The most effective route to resolving these issues is for Russia to call off this war
column2: de-escalate and end it and to withdraw from Ukraine. The European Union stands ready at all times in terms of a humanitarian response and to facilitate people
column3: such as conscientious soldiers
column4: who have no truck with this war and want to disengage. One will find that the European Union
column5: through all of its agencies
column6: will be facilitative and help out in that situation.

column1: #ThomasGould	unknown-#ThomasGould-party	unknown-#ThomasGould-dob	unknown-#ThomasGould-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	161	For far too many people
column2: the prospect of home ownership is moving further and further away. On 16 November 2019
column3: the then Taoiseach turned the first sod in the Boherboy Road development
column4: which was Cork City Council's first affordable housing scheme. Today
column5: those houses are built and lying idle and families have contacted me looking to buy them. It has been 224 days since the Affordable Housing Bill 2021 was passed and the Taoiseach and the Minister
column6: Deputy O'Brien
column7: have said they are serious about building houses. Why are houses lying idle in the middle of a housing crisis? Will the Taoiseach tell me when the Minister will sign these regulations in order that people can buy these houses?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	162	Which regulations?

#ThomasGould	unknown-#ThomasGould-party	unknown-#ThomasGould-dob	unknown-#ThomasGould-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	163	The Affordable Housing Bill 2021.

column2: I pay tribute to Cork corporation and the Minister
column3: because Cork has been to the fore and well-advanced in terms of affordable and social housing. It is ahead of most other places in terms of getting these projects done.

column1: #ThomasGould	unknown-#ThomasGould-party	unknown-#ThomasGould-dob	unknown-#ThomasGould-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	167	The houses are built. People want to buy them.

#EmerHiggins	unknown-#EmerHiggins-party	unknown-#EmerHiggins-dob	unknown-#EmerHiggins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	168	This week marks national eating disorders awareness week. I raise with the Taoiseach the damaging impact social media is having on the self-esteem and mental health of our young people
column2: in particular when it comes to eating disorders. Only a few months ago
column3: the Facebook whistleblower
column4: Ms Frances Haugen
column5: reported that Instagram targets pro-anorexia content towards young girls who show a vulnerability of low self-esteem and negative body image.The Instagram algorithm is basically selling these young people an eating disorder. Ireland is the European hub for almost all of our social media companies. We have responsibility to address these issues adequately in the Online Safety and Media Regulation Bill 2022. What is the Government doing to protect our young people from the dangerous manipulation of social media companies?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	169	That legislation is on Second Stage in the Seanad and represents the most effective way in which we can respond to this very serious issue. In parallel with that are the ongoing programmes in education in terms of building up self-esteem and self-respect among children at the earliest ages. There are a variety of psychologically-informed programmes that can help children to withstand pressures both in-person in yards and so on when meeting other kids in social environments and now with the growing threat from online content.

#JackieCahill	unknown-#JackieCahill-party	unknown-#JackieCahill-dob	unknown-#JackieCahill-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	170	I also wish to raise the issue of Ukraine. Our people are extremely concerned and worried about the safety and welfare of the people of Ukraine. There would be huge public support for terminating diplomatic relations with Russia and sending the Russian ambassador home. The fast-tracking of Ukraine’s entry into the EU would also be greeted with great relief and support among all people.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	171	I have articulated our support for the acceleration of Ukraine’s membership of the European Union. I made it very clear that in respect of diplomatic channels
column2: our primary concern is not the ambassador but rather Irish citizens who will need our assistance both in Ukraine and potentially Russia as well. We should not understate the seriousness of that in terms of helping people who right now are very vulnerable and need our assistance. We are getting representations from Deputies and Senators in respect of individuals who need our help right now. That is why it is important that we work in concert with our European Union colleagues on that front and work together in unity. What has been done so far by the European Union has been very strong. I understand people's anger at the Russian ambassador. The more fundamental point
column3: however
column4: is the importance of the well-being of our citizens and enabling them to be supported.

column1: #ImeldaMunster	unknown-#ImeldaMunster-party	unknown-#ImeldaMunster-dob	unknown-#ImeldaMunster-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	172	The Government's retrofitting scheme is geared towards homeowners but there is very little thought given to and even less protection for renters in private rented accommodation. If a landlord decides to retrofit his or her property
column2: he or she can ask the tenant to move out. One might ask where the tenant will go. When that work is done and the BER rating has improved in the property
column3: however
column4: the landlord is then exempt from the limits in the rent pressure zone
column5: RPZ
column6: and can hike up the rents. Although by law the landlord can invite the tenant to move back into property
column7: if he or she has hiked up the rents
column8: the tenant can no longer remain in that property because the rents have been hiked up. At the minute
column9: property websites are advertising this loophole as a selling point for properties. Threshold and the Residential Tenancies Board
column10: RTB
column11: have said this could potentially be a big problem with this scheme. What is the Government going to do to afford protections to renters in private rental accommodation under this scheme and address the problems it may pose for them?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	173	The first point I will make is that the retrofit scheme is very positive. It will provide very significant resources to households generally across the country in terms of insulation and reducing energy costs for ordinary people over time. It will take time to get to critical mass. A raft of protections have been introduced legislatively by the Minister
column2: whom I will alert to this issue. I know he is aware of it and I will discuss it with him.

column3: luaigh siad freisin na réitithe ar na fadhbanna sin. Tuigimid go léir an ról tábhachtach agus lárnach atá ag oifigí poist inár bpobail tuaithe agus i bpobail uirbeacha araon
column4: agus an caillteanas ollmhór a bheadh ann dá gcaillfí an gréasán sin. Tá dúshlán le sárú ag na hoifigí poist ina múnlú maoinithe agus aithníodh na dúshláin sin go maith i dtuarascáil Grant Thornton. Tá an ceardchumann ag moladh go maoinítear an tseirbhís trí choimeádán nó retainer

column2: tá dúshláin an-mhór ann don todhchaí. Níl aon amhras faoi sin. Tá fonn orainn níos mó seirbhísí ón Stát a chur ar fáil
column3: go háirithe in áiteanna iargúlta ar fud na tíre
column4: agus táimid sásta déileáil leis an gceardchumann chun na ceisteanna sin a phlé.

column1: #MarcMacSharry	unknown-#MarcMacSharry-party	unknown-#MarcMacSharry-dob	unknown-#MarcMacSharry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	176	As mentioned last week
column2: the programme for Government focuses on how we can improve services and be more responsive to citizens. As the Taoiseach may be aware
column3: the turnaround time for applications and renewals for passports at the moment is totally unacceptable. When I came into the Oireachtas 20 years ago
column4: we had a drop box in Leinster House that empowered Deputies and Senators to facilitate urgent passports for members of the public. Some 20 years later
column5: that box is long gone. It can take months
column6: never mind weeks
column7: particularly for young children and new applications. Indeed
column8: anecdotal evidence suggests that depending on who you know or what mobile telephone numbers you have
column9: the turnaround time can be a little bit better but for the vast majority of us
column10: it is disgraceful in the extreme. The process to become a UN envoy seems clearer to the public than managing to get a passport for a child
column11: to visit a sick relative or to go on a modest holiday.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	177	I thank the Deputy for raising the issue. An extra €10 million was allocated for the passport service in the budget
column2: which was an unprecedented investment in the service. Passport service staff numbers have increased by more than 300 since June of 2021 and additional staff will continue to be recruited
column3: which will bring the staff numbers to more than 900.

#PaulKehoeFG	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-party	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-dob	unknown-#PaulKehoeFG-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	192	The Taoiseach will be very much aware of the devastating flooding in County Wexford on 25 December last. In south County Wexford
column2: hundreds of acres of cereals were destroyed. At the time
column3: the Department of Agriculture
column4: Food and the Marine committed to look into this issue and seek the names of the farmers and lands involved. To date
column5: absolutely nothing has happened. There has been a wall of silence from the Minister and the Department. Can the Taoiseach bring some clarification to this issue?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	193	I will discuss that with the Minister for Agriculture
column2: Food and the Marine. I hear the points the Deputy made in respect of that issue. The Minister is actively considering this and we are working on it.

column1: #MartinBrowne	unknown-#MartinBrowne-party	unknown-#MartinBrowne-dob	unknown-#MartinBrowne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	194	I recently raised the issue of the lack of an autism spectrum disorder
column2: ASD
column3: unit in Carrick-on-Suir and to be honest
column4: the discussions I have had with the Department on the matter since have been unsatisfactory. There seems to be an attempt to overestimate the number of spaces available at neighbouring schools. I want to talk about Sacred Heart Primary School in Roscrea
column5: which had an exceptional review of its mainstream special needs assistant
column6: SNA
column7: allocation in October of last year. The school made this request because in summer 2020
column8: it knew the allocated SNA resources for its mainstream classes were not adequate. Despite numerous emails to the visiting special educational needs organiser
column9: SENO
column10: who carried out the review
column11: the school has heard nothing back since. That has been going on six months into the school year. As a consequence
column12: the school has had no SENO in place since 24 September 2021. As the Taoiseach will appreciate
column13: this is a huge loss locally for the parents and children within the school community. To keep a school in the dark in this way is unacceptable. I am hopeful something can be done to address this immediately. I certainly hope this is not the trend being experienced by other schools and parents around the country.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	195	As the Deputy is aware
column2: the NCSE allocates special needs assistants to schools. Record numbers of SNAs have been allocated again this year. The range of resources for special education continues to significantly increase year on year. I will refer the Deputy’s case
column3: as well as the issue that he has raised
column4: to the NCSE for a response.

column1: #DannyHealyRae	unknown-#DannyHealyRae-party	unknown-#DannyHealyRae-dob	unknown-#DannyHealyRae-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	196	As I have done several times before
column2: I wish to raise with the Taoiseach today the issue of funding for the local improvement schemes in Kerry. As I said
column3: I raised this several times last year. I even got the Deputy Chief Whip
column4: Deputy Griffin
column5: interested in the scheme as well. We have had a new list since 2018
column6: which includes applicants since 2007. We got 19 roads done last year. At this rate
column7: it will take 34 or 35 years to complete or to exhaust this list. These are public roads
column8: not private roads like the Department of Finance has said. There is no gate on any one of them. People on these roads pay for everything
column9: from motor tax
column10: to property tax
column11: to income tax. They are ordinary working-class people
column12: people who are going to work
column13: farmers and elderly people who require carers and home help to visit them. Other counties have been allocated funding in proportion to what is on the local improvement scheme list.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	197	The funding was doubled from €10 million to €20 million. The Deputy should acknowledge that.

#NeasaHourigan	unknown-#NeasaHourigan-party	unknown-#NeasaHourigan-dob	unknown-#NeasaHourigan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	212	I move:That leave be granted to introduce a Bill entitled an Act to provide for the amendment of the Planning and Development Act 2000 in order to restrict developments in Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) infrastructure and to remove LNG infrastructure from listing as strategic development infrastructure projects.I want to introduce this Bill today by quoting the Tánaiste in his speech in this House last week. He said: "Even if it was not for the climate crisis
column2: for economic and security reasons
column3: we need to wean ourselves off our dependence on fossil fuels." The position outlined last week in this House is meaningful and it is hopeful
column4: because for once and at last
column5: it places our communities
column6: our children and our grandchildren at the forefront of policymaking in energy in this country. It sets out our plan for energy security. The LNG free Bill
column7: which I have tabled today
column8: was developed by the grassroots organisation Not Here Not Anywhere - who are here today and to which I am incredibly thankful - and it is sponsored by me. It seeks to support the Government's agreed position
column9: as outlined in the programme for Government. This Bill is also supported by 30 national and international organisations. It is to keep Ireland free of liquefied natural gas and to strike out towards a future based on energy sustainability and security
column10: a future that will deliver us from the clutches of profiteers and despots who would happily allow this world to burn for the sake of a few more dollars. This Government will not and cannot allow that to happen. These have been a challenging two years for all of us. Just when we began to emerge from the Covid-19 crisis
column11: inflation has skyrocketed
column12: particularly in energy costs. This is placing households in Ireland under terrible and sustained pressure. No one should have to decide between heat or food. It is our generation that will decide the pathway forward. The pathway for which I advocate
column13: and which this Bill serves
column14: is one where communities can produce their own energy. They own it. They benefit from it. It provides jobs to their communities. It uses local natural resources
column15: without destroying those resources or the landscape around them. That is an attainable vision for energy in this country. It includes wind
column16: solar and perhaps wave energy. It must include an integrated European grid. Given our geographical riches and demographics in Ireland
column17: Ireland has a better chance than almost any country on this planet of being entirely energy independent. That will be mostly due to renewables. We are the country that could achieve this.  The other path to take would be the LNG path. The impacts of that were outlined in detail this week by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
column18: IPCC
column19: report
column20: which issued a stark warning on just how close we are to devastation as a result of climate change. Building large-scale LNG infrastructure in Ireland at this point will lock us into fossil fuel-use for decades to come. It is an even worse path than that
column21: because it is a polluted path. It is a dangerous and dirty industry. It is huge in the space that it requires but it is minuscule in the provision of employment.  The oppressive threat of environmental degradation and safety issues looms not just for those who suffer as their communities are ravaged by fracking and shale gas extraction in places like the US and Qatar
column22: but for communities here in Ireland
column23: where LNG terminals are to be built
column24: as huge polluting tankers hover on the horizon and a meagre cohort of workers tend to often-empty storage facilities. LNG did not protect France or Germany from price surges this year. It did not protect their communities from inflation. It did not protect communities in other countries from fuel poverty
column25: even when it polluted them. LNG is a plaything of private investors
column26: and for this we will turn away from a truly fossil-free future. We will give up our opportunity over the coming decades for an energy security that is genuinely ours. The past two weeks has shown us how truly powerful the reliance on gas can be and how it can shape geopolitics. If we are committed to peace and to standing for democracy
column27: we can no longer blindly bind ourselves through energy dependence to other nations
column28: especially when we now have options. We can no longer place the future of our communities
column29: their employment
column30: their prosperity
column31: their very environment and their water and air quality in the hands of other nations or
column32: in particular
column33: in the hands of private investors and interests. The future should belong to us
column34: to Irish communities
column35: and it is for us to safeguard it for those who come after us. There is no place for LNG in Ireland. We do not need it. I commend the Bill to the House.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	answer	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	218	I propose to take Questions Nos. 1 to 8
column2: inclusive
column3: together. The international section of the Department supports my work at international level
column4: beyond the European Union
column5: to promote Ireland's foreign and economic policy objectives and to maintain and develop strong bilateral and multilateral relations. Working closely with other Departments
column6: including the Department of Foreign Affairs

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	219	The Taoiseach has rightly referred to crimes against humanity and against international law committed by Vladimir Putin. Tonight in the Dáil
column2: we will discuss the Amnesty International report entitled
column3: Israel's Apartheid Against Palestinians: A Cruel System of Domination and a Crime Against Humanity. The report asks European governments
column4: including the Taoiseach's Government
column5: to condemn Israel for ongoing
column6: systematic crimes against humanity. Is the Taoiseach going to endorse that report and its recommendations regarding the referral of Israel to the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity
column7: a total arms embargo against the state of Israel
column8: and targeted sanctions against Israeli officials who perpetuate the system of apartheid
column9: very similar to the sanctions the Government has just agreed to against members of the Kremlin and Putin's coterie for crimes against humanity? If the Government does not do those things
column10: it will be guilty
column11: as will the European Union
column12: of gross double standards in supposedly opposing crimes against humanity and breaches of international law.

column1: #PaulMurphy	unknown-#PaulMurphy-party	unknown-#PaulMurphy-dob	unknown-#PaulMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	220	I wish to ask the Taoiseach about his position on the newly published draft corporate sustainability due diligence directive from the European Commission. We desperately need laws ensuring corporate accountability throughout the supply chain
column2: regarding human rights
column3: labour rights and environmental rights
column4: but it appears the Commission has gone for the lowest common denominator position
column5: with loopholes to carve out the vast majority of corporations in this country and across the EU. For example
column6: 99% of Irish businesses would be excluded because the proposed legislation will apply only to companies with an annual turnover of more than €150 million and with more than 500 employees. That would exclude
column7: for example
column8: the Dublin-based Coal Marketing Company
column9: which sells coal from the infamous Cerrejón mine in Colombia
column10: from where communities nearby face pollution of their air and water. Another loophole would allow companies to offload responsibility through a contract onto their suppliers. Will the Taoiseach work to strengthen this proposal?

column1: #LouiseOReilly	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-party	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-dob	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	221	I send my solidarity to the Ukrainian people and their families in Ireland and commend those who are doing so much on the ground in our communities to organise relief
column2: collect money and show support. Two people in my town
column3: Tanya
column4: who runs Tanya's Kitchen
column5: and her mam
column6: both of them Ukrainian
column7: will run a fundraiser tomorrow
column8: while Ollie
column9: who runs The Snug
column10: is collecting money as well. So much work is being done and we have much to be proud of. I hope yesterday's Dáil statements demonstrated our collective support for Ukraine and our deep opposition to Russia's morally bankrupt and illegal war. In light of Ireland's military neutrality
column11: our seat on the UN Security Council and our position as an EU member state not aligned with NATO
column12: we have a unique and important role in supporting Ukraine
column13: making the case for peace and holding Russia to account for its war crimes. As for sanctions and
column14: specifically
column15: the targeting of Russian oligarchs and their financial entities located in Ireland
column16: just three of the 34 of these special purpose entities will be impacted by the current round of sanctions. I am concerned there appears to be no intention to pursue the remaining 31 entities. Will the Taoiseach clarify the position? Over the past two years
column17: my party colleague Deputy Mairéad Farrell has raised a special purpose vehicle provision in section 110 in Ireland's tax code that is used by these Russian entities and others to avoid regulation and tax. Does the Taoiseach accept it is finally time to reform how the International Financial Services Centre
column18: IFSC
column19: and our tax code are used
column20: how our financial regulation performs and how our rules on transparency of company ownership work?

column1: #PeadarToibin	unknown-#PeadarToibin-party	unknown-#PeadarToibin-dob	unknown-#PeadarToibin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	222	The Currency has an article today on its website that indicates it has tracked about €13 billion domiciled in the IFSC by sanctioned Russian firms. The Irish Times has stated that about €34 billion is held in opaque Russian-linked shell companies registered in the IFSC. Colm Keena published a report in 2020 that showed a network of bank accounts allowing Russia to funnel money into the West. Cillian Doyle and Jim Stewart have carried out research that shows that €118 billion has been moved by Russian companies through section 110 trusts based in the IFSC over a 12-year period. All the rhetoric we use in this House will come to nothing if we do not show Ukraine that we mean business by ensuring these sanctions are not circumvented through the IFSC. What will the Taoiseach do to make sure that is the case?

#MickBarry	unknown-#MickBarry-party	unknown-#MickBarry-dob	unknown-#MickBarry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	223	Yesterday in this House
column2: I questioned the Taoiseach about reports of people of colour fleeing Ukraine
column3: being discriminated against at the Polish border and being turned away. In his reply
column4: he stated
column5: "we neither support nor have any evidence ... of any racist approach to facilitating migration into Poland". There is plenty of evidence now. Ignorance was not really an excuse yesterday
column6: given a Government Deputy
column7: Deputy Higgins
column8: raised the matter in the Dáil yesterday evening
column9: but it is certainly no excuse today. This has been reported by the BBC
column10: CNN
column11: Reuters
column12: France 24
column13: The Guardian and others. I give the Taoiseach a second opportunity to join with me in voicing opposition to a racist border policy at the Polish border with Ukraine and to call for equal treatment for everyone fleeing this humanitarian crisis.

column1: #RuairiOmurchu	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-party	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-dob	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	224	There has been significant solidarity with Ukraine and against the war criminality of Vladimir Putin. We all agree we need to hurt the Russian and oligarchs' war machine financially. We need to deal with the section 110 companies and the various means by which money can be filtered that have enabled these people. There has been great success regarding people who have contacted us about medical supplies
column2: particularly insulin. This was facilitated
column3: but many people are still talking about the community response.The EU Commission is talking about this becoming a major part of dealing with migration into the future. People have approached me in Dundalk and I would appreciate it if the Taoiseach could lay out for us what the process will be for people who are willing to take those who are fleeing war-torn Ukraine.

column1: #SeanHaughey	unknown-#SeanHaughey-party	unknown-#SeanHaughey-dob	unknown-#SeanHaughey-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	225	I am glad to learn more about the international unit in the Department of the Taoiseach. It is obviously doing important work. As we all will be aware
column2: international affairs are dominated just now by the horrific Russian war on Ukraine. The Taoiseach has engaged with a number of Heads of Government in this regard in recent days. Can the Taoiseach give me a sense of where world leaders are at on this? I think
column3: in particular
column4: of the Taoiseach's formal visit to Germany last week and his meeting with the German Chancellor
column5: Mr. Olaf Scholz
column6: just prior to the invasion. It seems
column7: after some initial apparent hesitation by the German Chancellor
column8: he has now become one of the strongest supporters for harsh sanctions on Russia. For example
column9: he has cancelled the Nord Stream 2 pipeline project. Is the Taoiseach aware of any new initiatives by EU leaders as we witness the horrific scenes taking place in Ukraine? Finally
column10: in his exchanges with President Biden for St. Patrick's Day
column11: what will the Taoiseach be saying to him in this regard? Have the Taoiseach's plans for his visit to Washington been finalised at this stage?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	226	I thank the Deputies for raising the issues. In respect of Deputy Boyd Barrett's question in terms of the Amnesty report
column2: Amnesty International is a respected NGO. I value the role it has played and the role other civil society organisations have played in relation to the Palestinian question. The Department of Foreign Affairs is currently examining the Amnesty report in respect of the plight of the Palestinian people. I have consistently opposed the policy of successive Israeli Governments in relation to Palestine. It is my view that a two-state solution is the optimal solution to what has been a very long-running conflict. It is unacceptable how Palestinians have been and are being treated and the discriminatory practices that have been deployed towards them on a regular basis by the Israeli authorities.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	236	-----there are many formulaic responses to Ukraine and then the Deputy very hurriedly wants to move on to other issues. Anyway
column2: I will say no more than that. Deputy Paul Murphy spoke about the corporate sustainability due diligence EU directive. We support greater corporate accountability. The European Union has done far more than most across the world in terms of corporate sustainability policies and directives
column3: as well as accountability and holding people to task. Through the various layers of both legal and judicial agencies within the European Union
column4: that has been seen on an ongoing basis in terms of companies being brought before European courts or the Commission and being tackled in relation to a range of issues. I do not accept the criticism of the European Union
column5: which is a consistent theme of Deputy Paul Murphy and others-----

column5: the Central Bank has advised that total Russian assets held on 31 December 2021 is estimated at €11.4 billion or 0.3% of the total Irish fund assets of €3.8 trillion
column6: and this is evenly split between equities and bonds. In terms of the special purpose entities
column7: there were 3
column8: 000 Irish domiciled special purpose entities. The Central Bank has undertaken an initial review of those and any links with Russian counterparts. Some 34 of these entities have a Russian sponsor
column9: meaning that they were established on behalf of a Russian company. By the way
column10: it does not mean they are all illegal. Of these 34 entities
column11: three have been identified as being directly linked to individuals or financial institutions covered in the 23 February round of EU sanctions. Work is ongoing in respect of the subsequent sanction rounds. I have given the figure in terms of the €11.4 billion
column12: which is 0.3% of the €3.8 trillion. I would make the point that a breach of a financial sanction
column13: and this is in response to Deputy Tóibín as well
column14: is a criminal offence. Accounts
column15: funds or other assets must be frozen without delay in order that they cannot be made available
column16: directly or indirectly
column17: to the sanctioned person
column18: entity or body
column19: and all natural and legal persons in the State are obliged to comply with European Union sanctions.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	answer	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	251	I propose to take Questions Nos. 9 to 17
column2: inclusive
column3: together. The economic division in my Department supports me and the Government in developing and implementing policy to support sustainable economic development in areas such as job creation
column4: housing
column5: climate action
column6: digital issues and well-being. This work is particularly focused on ensuring a co-ordinated approach to the delivery of the programme for Government and issues that cut across multiple Departments. The division supports the work of the Cabinet committee on economic recovery and investment
column7: the Cabinet committee on housing and the Cabinet committee on the environment and climate change
column8: as well as associated senior officials groups and other cross-departmental structures. The division also includes a unit which supports strengthening of social dialogue
column9: including the Labour Employer Economic Forum.

column1: #PeadarToibin	unknown-#PeadarToibin-party	unknown-#PeadarToibin-dob	unknown-#PeadarToibin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	252	I wanted to raise something with the Taoiseach in relation to a report that was delivered by Down Syndrome Ireland
column2: DSI
column3: in the past couple of days. It relates to the fact that services delivered to people with Down's syndrome have radically fallen over the past couple of years. Of those surveyed by DSI
column4: 65% have received no speech and language therapy sessions in the past year
column5: while 44% have received no therapy of any kind in the past year. Some parents responded that they have received no therapy sessions at all over the past three years. Moreover
column6: 40% stated they received no communication from the HSE in the past 12 months and nearly 25% of children with Down's syndrome under the age of five have received no therapy services in their whole lives. Of young children
column7: only 49% have had a speech and language therapist
column8: while 22% have had access to occupational therapy.This is an abandonment of a whole section of Irish society. This country flies the flag of inclusion but
column9: unfortunately
column10: in real terms
column11: too many people with disabilities are being excluded.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	253	The Trans-European Transport Network
column2: TEN-T
column3: policy is a gateway that gives specific rail and road transport infrastructure
column4: routes
column5: ports and airports exclusive access to the Connecting Europe Facility
column6: CEF
column7: fund. It also represents the individual member states' priority rail and road transport corridors
column8: ports and airports. The latest 2021 CEF transport call under the 2013 TEN-T map is for proposals to make €7 billion available to support infrastructure projects across the EU. Why is the west and the Atlantic economic corridor excluded from the TEN-T core status when it is critical to provide investment certainty and to match EU and State investment in the infrastructure there? People in the west need to know why they are being excluded and why they do not have the vital infrastructure that would create the opportunities that are presented by renewable energy and related industries in the west.

column1: #MickBarry	unknown-#MickBarry-party	unknown-#MickBarry-dob	unknown-#MickBarry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	254	Breaking news
column2: Eurozone inflation is 5.8%.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	255	I said that this morning.

#MickBarry	unknown-#MickBarry-party	unknown-#MickBarry-dob	unknown-#MickBarry-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	256	Wow. It is 5.8%. The Taoiseach may have said it this morning
column2: but it is breaking in the past hour. There are big cost-of-living increases on the way that are not included in those figures. The Russian invasion of Ukraine moves the cost-of-living crisis to another level. The price of bread
column3: groceries
column4: heating and fuel will rise. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has already warned of a massive spike in heating costs. The Taoiseach is on the record as saying that there will be no new cost-of-living compensation measures for households this side of the budget in October. I put it to him that this is no longer a tenable position. I am for price controls on gas and electricity prices. I am also for an increase in the national minimum wage to €15 and for inflation-busting wage increases across the board. What new measures is the Taoiseach prepared to consider? What is his position
column5: for example
column6: on the idea that a €200 credit be introduced to offset rising gas bills?

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	257	What is also breaking news
column2: is that the Department of Finance told me yesterday that on top of the current rate of inflation of 5.8%
column3: the conflict in Ukraine and the sanctions relating to it are likely to increase inflation by a further 4%. As a result
column4: we are potentially looking at an inflation rate of more than 9%. Against that background
column5: and because I did not make this point earlier
column6: could I ask the Taoiseach to condemn what Aer Lingus and International Airlines Group
column7: IAG
column8: are doing in terms of demanding pay cuts? This from an entity that we subsidised during Covid. I commend the workers on voting overwhelmingly against those pay cuts
column9: particularly - I did not make this point earlier - because IAG
column10: simultaneously gave British Airways workers
column11: the same staff
column12: a 10% pay increase as a reward for what they had done during Covid. That is shocking. What is the Taoiseach going to do to increase the minimum wage for low-paid workers? I met this week with private security workers who are on less than €12 an hour. Do they not deserve a decent pay increase?

column1: #PaulMurphy	unknown-#PaulMurphy-party	unknown-#PaulMurphy-dob	unknown-#PaulMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	258	I also want to talk about the Aer Lingus ground staff. They very decisively rejected a proposal to impose a pay freeze and cuts to allowances on them today
column2: voting 85% against. Fair play to them. These are workers who have not had a pay rise since 2019
column3: and the Labour Court was pushing to continue with the pay freeze for almost three more years when the cost of living is through the roof
column4: as the himself has now pointed out. At the same time
column5: IAG is now granting 10% pay increases at other airlines. Does the Taoiseach agree that a pay freeze is simply not fair during this cost-of-living crisis? Will he support these workers and oppose the attempts right across the aviation industry to use the pandemic to reshape labour relations in the interests of the bosses against the workers
column6: for example
column7: as we have seen at the Dublin Airport Authority
column8: DAA
column9: where it got a significant number of workers to sign up for severance and has rehired people on substantially worse terms and conditions?

column1: #LouiseOReilly	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-party	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-dob	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	259	I want to ask the Taoiseach about the abolition of mandatory retirement. As he will be aware
column2: Sinn Féin tabled legislation that was supported by his party in opposition in the previous Dáil and which we will be reintroducing in the coming weeks. This legislation
column3: when passed
column4: will give workers a choice to retire at 65 or to work on. Forcing workers to retire at 65
column5: as his Government partners are finding out
column6: when they are fit and able and may want to work on
column7: especially where they cannot access the State pension rate of pay
column8: is deeply unfair. Will the Taoiseach elaborate on any discussions that have taken place and any work done on this important worker's rights issue by the economic division of his Department? This morning
column9: Ms Patricia King
column10: the general secretary of the Irish Congress of Trade Unions
column11: ICTU
column12: outlined deep concerns that she and ICTU affiliates have in relation to a complete lack of consultation on the right to request remote working. The matter is being referred to in industrial relations circles as the right for employers to say no to remote working. The lack of consultation led to deeply flawed legislation. We do not want to see that mistake replicated. What consultation and discussions have taken place on the abolition of mandatory retirement?

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	260	In response to Deputy Tóibín
column2: I have not seen the report. His question related to the economic division in my Department. Suffice to say that throughout the Covid period there was
column3: unfortunately
column4: a retrenchment in services. We have provided additional resources to the HSE in respect of the hiring of occupational therapists
column5: physiotherapists and speech and language therapists. I will discuss this further with the HSE and the Minister of State with responsibility for disability regarding the report on Down's syndrome and we will follow through on it. There is a need to provide far greater therapeutic services to children with special needs more generally. Additional funding has been allocated in successive years. I am not clear whether the allocation has been provided specifically to services on the ground. We need to interrogate a bit further the money that has been allocated. Record funding has been allocated to the HSE in respect of therapeutic services
column6: in particular in terms of the progressing disability model it has been pursuing for some years. Deputy Conway-Walsh referred to the west.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	261	TEN-T funding.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	262	I know. It was about TEN-T funding
column2: but that is not the core funding. The core funding is in the national development plan in respect of roads and public transport. A sum of €165 billion is being provided over the next ten years for investment in infrastructure in the west. The Deputy referred to the development of renewable energy in particular. The western seaboard will receive considerable investment for renewable energy. The first phase is on the east coast and the west and south west will follow through. There is great potential in particular for offshore wind on the western seaboard. The potential is very exciting in terms of jobs and the economy in the future. The ring road around Galway
column3: for example
column4: is a major piece of infrastructure that has been bogged down in planning due to objections right through the process. I understand it is currently subject to a judicial review.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	263	What about the western rail corridor?

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	264	Yes
column2: that has been included in the all-island rail strategy review that the shared island unit in my Department is helping to fund in order to identify the potential in that regard. There has been very significant investment in the urban regeneration and development fund
column3: URDF
column4: programme by the Minister for Housing
column5: Local Government and Heritage
column6: Deputy Darragh O'Brien
column7: in respect of many towns across the west. There is a whole range of investment vehicles from the State and the vast bulk of the investment is now generated by taxpayers and allocated through the various national strategies in terms of investment in the west. In response to Deputy Barry
column8: as I referenced this morning
column9: there is a significant issue facing the country in the context of inflation. It is a global phenomenon. There are no easy answers. The invasion of Ukraine by Russia
column10: an illegal war
column11: is going to add to inflation
column12: in particular in respect of energy prices.I said earlier that in 2020
column13: the country spent approximately €3.4 billion on imported fuels. In 2021
column14: it spent €6.2 billion. That gives an illustration. There was a €2.8 billion increase in the bill for imported fuels and that reflects the higher prices on the international markets. A year ago
column15: a barrel of oil cost $64 on international markets. Today
column16: it costs $110. Oil prices have risen by $14 a barrel over the past week. This is not the Government's fault. It is just the reality of the international situation in regard to energy.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	265	How strange.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	266	The Deputy got his chance. The same applies to natural gas
column2: which costs 400p per therm today on international markets compared with 40p per therm last March. Gas prices have soared 220p per therm over the past week. We are going to face a very difficult situation. I gave the figures on wages
column3: which have increased over the past while. In terms of the Government's response
column4: we have increased the fuel allowance from €630 to €1
column5: 039 since we came into office a little over a year and a half ago. If we add on the €200 electricity payment
column6: that is €1
column7: 239 we are giving to low-income families. Basically
column8: it is a doubling of support to low-income families in the context of fuel supports. We have also taken other measures to support families
column9: either with medical costs or in respect of reducing transport fees from the end of April
column10: which will benefit approximately 800
column11: 000 users
column12: and by reducing school transport fees. The budget contained in the region of €1 billion in measures to support people on social protection and tax relief for workers of about €630 million. We are and will be working with the European Commission in respect of the energy situation and energy prices. The European Commission will be coming forward with a further publication in that regard in the next ten days following the Russian invasion of Ukraine. We are facing a very difficult situation because of the war and because of President Putin's behaviour and activity. There is no question about that. There are no easy answers. It is pointless coming in and making ideological points or whatever. That is the point I would make.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	267	Wait until October.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	268	In respect of the situation in Aer Lingus
column2: as I said earlier
column3: the Government supported the workers in Aer Lingus through the employment wage subsidy scheme and supported the company
column4: along with other companies in aviation. Many people in the House were calling for that and we did it. The workers should be treated fairly and
column5: in my view
column6: on a par with UK employees in the same overall company.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	269	We are way over time. We must proceed to the next group of questions.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	270	We support the end of mandatory retirement. The Pensions Commission has reported on that and it will come back to Government.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	answer	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	271	I propose to take Questions Nos. 18 to 25
column2: inclusive
column3: together. I participated in the One Ocean Summit in Brest
column4: France
column5: on Friday
column6: 11 February. Around 20 international leaders attended in person for Friday's high-level segment hosted by President Macron. This event was held in the context of the French Presidency of the Council of the European Union
column7: with the support of the UN and in co-operation with the World Bank and other public
column8: private and civil society partners. It feeds into a sequence of major international events on the oceans and seas in the first half of 2022
column9: including a meeting of the United Nations Environment Assembly
column10: the second phase of the COP15 UN biodiversity conference and a UN conference to support the implementation of sustainable development Goal 14
column11: which is to conserve and sustainably use the oceans
column12: seas and marine resources for sustainable development. My contribution to the One Ocean Summit was on the theme of "an ocean of solutions to climate change". I took the opportunity to highlight the following: the vast potential of Ireland's renewable energy resources
column13: including for export
column14: and associated commitments in our climate action plan and programme for government; the new licensing and regulatory regime being established by the Maritime Area Planning Act
column15: including establishment of the maritime area regulatory authority; and the launch this year of Ireland's new state-of-the-art marine research vessel
column16: RV Tom Crean
column17: which will make an important contribution to the Horizon Europe mission to restore our ocean
column18: seas and waters by 2030. The oceans comprise the largest component of the Earth's system that stabilises climate and supports life and human well-being. Given that our maritime area is seven times the size of our landmass
column19: it also has particular significance for Ireland. I was happy to lend my firm support for this excellent initiative from President Macron to raise the collective level of ambition of the international community on marine issues. I pay tribute to President Macron for the enormous individual effort that he put into this conference
column20: staying there for the entirety of it and contributing very significantly to it.

column1: #SeanSherlock	Labour	17983	Cork East	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	272	I welcome the fact that the Taoiseach attended the summit
column2: which is to be acknowledged. Is the Taoiseach confident that Ireland can achieve the 5 GW of installed offshore wind generation by 2030
column3: which is the Government's own target? Is he confident that upon the establishment of the maritime agency
column4: the marine area consents that would give effect to the potential for offshore wind will be realised? There is a massive opportunity in our native Cork for sites like the Verolme dockyard to be staging posts to service that industry
column5: particularly on the south and south-west coast.

column1: #LouiseOReilly	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-party	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-dob	unknown-#LouiseOReilly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	273	I want to raise with the Taoiseach the delay in advancing the urgently needed legislation to identify and guard marine protected areas as required under the marine strategy framework directive. As the Taoiseach will be aware
column2: Ireland has no legal tool with which to define
column3: identify
column4: designate or manage marine protected areas. As a result
column5: many species
column6: habitats and processes occurring in our extensive marine area have fallen outside the scope of area-based conservation
column7: with consequent risks to marine biodiversity and ecosystem services that benefit people and nature. These are not my words. This is the advice of a senior Department official to a recent meeting of an Oireachtas committee. It is also worth noting that under the directive
column8: Ireland's marine protected area should have been identified and underpinned in legislation two years ago. Nearly three years have passed since the Dáil declared a climate and biodiversity emergency
column9: yet numerous targets set out in the national biodiversity action plan have not been met. Again
column10: the Taoiseach will know from his keen interest in biodiversity that international best practice dictates that the marine planning framework should have been delivered in tandem with the marine protected areas legislation. In addition to the marine biodiversity protection targets that Ireland has missed and has yet to meet
column11: there are seven renewable energy legacy projects
column12: as well as new planning applications
column13: that will be dealt with in the absence of the marine protected areas legislation.

column1: #PeadarToibin	unknown-#PeadarToibin-party	unknown-#PeadarToibin-dob	unknown-#PeadarToibin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-03-02 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	274	The Irish fishing fleet is to be gutted by one third and 60 trawlers are to be scrapped by the Government
column2: which will leave 100 vessels in the fleet. Fishing ports such as Burtonport
column3: An Daingean
column4: Schull
